8591
8592class TestNakagami:
8593
8594 def test_logpdf(self):
8595 # Test nakagami logpdf for an input where the PDF is smaller
8596 # than can be represented with 64 bit floating point.
8597 # The expected value of logpdf was computed with mpmath:
8598 #
8599 # def logpdf(x, nu):
8600 # x = mpmath.mpf(x)
8601 # nu = mpmath.mpf(nu)
8602 # return (mpmath.log(2) + nu*mpmath.log(nu) -
8603 # mpmath.loggamma(nu) + (2*nu - 1)*mpmath.log(x) -
8604 # nu*x**2)
8605 #
8606 nu = 2.5
8607 x = 25
8608 logp = stats.nakagami.logpdf(x, nu)
8609 assert_allclose(logp, -1546.9253055607549)
8610
8611 def test_sf_isf(self):
8612 # Test nakagami sf and isf when the survival function
8613 # value is very small.
8614 # The expected value of the survival function was computed
8615 # with mpmath:
8616 #
8617 # def sf(x, nu):
8618 # x = mpmath.mpf(x)
8619 # nu = mpmath.mpf(nu)
8620 # return mpmath.gammainc(nu, nu*x*x, regularized=True)
8621 #
8622 nu = 2.5
8623 x0 = 5.0
8624 sf = stats.nakagami.sf(x0, nu)
8625 assert_allclose(sf, 2.736273158588307e-25, rtol=1e-13)
8626 # Check round trip back to x0.
8627 x1 = stats.nakagami.isf(sf, nu)
8628 assert_allclose(x1, x0, rtol=1e-13)
8629
8630 @pytest.mark.parametrize("m, ref",
8631 [(5, -0.097341814372152),
8632 (0.5, 0.7257913526447274),
8633 (10, -0.43426184310934907)])
8634 def test_entropy(self, m, ref):
8635 # from sympy import *
8636 # from mpmath import mp
8637 # import numpy as np
8638 # v, x = symbols('v, x', real=True, positive=True)
8639 # pdf = 2 * v ** v / gamma(v) * x ** (2 * v - 1) * exp(-v * x ** 2)
8640 # h = simplify(simplify(integrate(-pdf * log(pdf), (x, 0, oo))))
8641 # entropy = lambdify(v, h, 'mpmath')
8642 # mp.dps = 200
8643 # nu = 5
8644 # ref = np.float64(entropy(mp.mpf(nu)))
8645 # print(ref)
8646 assert_allclose(stats.nakagami.entropy(m), ref, rtol=1.1e-14)
8647
8648 @pytest.mark.parametrize("m, ref",
8649 [(1e-100, -5.0e+99), (1e-10, -4999999965.442979),
8650 (9.999e6, -7.333206478668433), (1.001e7, -7.3337562313259825),
8651 (1e10, -10.787134112333835), (1e100, -114.40346329705756)])
8652 def test_extreme_nu(self, m, ref):
8653 assert_allclose(stats.nakagami.entropy(m), ref)
8654
8655 def test_entropy_overflow(self):
8656 assert np.isfinite(stats.nakagami._entropy(1e100))
8657 assert np.isfinite(stats.nakagami._entropy(1e-100))
8658
8659 @pytest.mark.xfail(reason="Fit of nakagami not reliable, see gh-10908.")
8660 @pytest.mark.parametrize('nu', [1.6, 2.5, 3.9])
8661 @pytest.mark.parametrize('loc', [25.0, 10, 35])
8662 @pytest.mark.parametrize('scale', [13, 5, 20])
8663 def test_fit(self, nu, loc, scale):
8664 # Regression test for gh-13396 (21/27 cases failed previously)
8665 # The first tuple of the parameters' values is discussed in gh-10908
8666 N = 100
8667 samples = stats.nakagami.rvs(size=N, nu=nu, loc=loc,
8668 scale=scale, random_state=1337)
8669 nu_est, loc_est, scale_est = stats.nakagami.fit(samples)
8670 assert_allclose(nu_est, nu, rtol=0.2)
8671 assert_allclose(loc_est, loc, rtol=0.2)
8672 assert_allclose(scale_est, scale, rtol=0.2)
8673
8674 def dlogl_dnu(nu, loc, scale):
8675 return ((-2*nu + 1) * np.sum(1/(samples - loc))
8676 + 2*nu/scale**2 * np.sum(samples - loc))
8677
8678 def dlogl_dloc(nu, loc, scale):
8679 return (N * (1 + np.log(nu) - polygamma(0, nu)) +
8680 2 * np.sum(np.log((samples - loc) / scale))
8681 - np.sum(((samples - loc) / scale)**2))
8682
8683 def dlogl_dscale(nu, loc, scale):
8684 return (- 2 * N * nu / scale
8685 + 2 * nu / scale ** 3 * np.sum((samples - loc) ** 2))
8686
8687 assert_allclose(dlogl_dnu(nu_est, loc_est, scale_est), 0, atol=1e-3)
8688 assert_allclose(dlogl_dloc(nu_est, loc_est, scale_est), 0, atol=1e-3)
8689 assert_allclose(dlogl_dscale(nu_est, loc_est, scale_est), 0, atol=1e-3)
8690
8691 @pytest.mark.parametrize('loc', [25.0, 10, 35])
8692 @pytest.mark.parametrize('scale', [13, 5, 20])
8693 def test_fit_nu(self, loc, scale):
8694 # For nu = 0.5, we have analytical values for
8695 # the MLE of the loc and the scale
8696 nu = 0.5
8697 n = 100
8698 samples = stats.nakagami.rvs(size=n, nu=nu, loc=loc,
8699 scale=scale, random_state=1337)
8700 nu_est, loc_est, scale_est = stats.nakagami.fit(samples, f0=nu)
8701
8702 # Analytical values
8703 loc_theo = np.min(samples)
8704 scale_theo = np.sqrt(np.mean((samples - loc_est) ** 2))
8705
8706 assert_allclose(nu_est, nu, rtol=1e-7)
8707 assert_allclose(loc_est, loc_theo, rtol=1e-7)
8708 assert_allclose(scale_est, scale_theo, rtol=1e-7)
8709
8710
8711class TestWrapCauchy:
8712
8713 def test_cdf_shape_broadcasting(self):
8714 # Regression test for gh-13791.
8715 # Check that wrapcauchy.cdf broadcasts the shape parameter
8716 # correctly.
8717 c = np.array([[0.03, 0.25], [0.5, 0.75]])
8718 x = np.array([[1.0], [4.0]])
8719 p = stats.wrapcauchy.cdf(x, c)
8720 assert p.shape == (2, 2)
8721 scalar_values = [stats.wrapcauchy.cdf(x1, c1)
8722 for (x1, c1) in np.nditer((x, c))]
8723 assert_allclose(p.ravel(), scalar_values, rtol=1e-13)
8724
8725 def test_cdf_center(self):
8726 p = stats.wrapcauchy.cdf(np.pi, 0.03)
8727 assert_allclose(p, 0.5, rtol=1e-14)
8728
8729 def test_cdf(self):
8730 x1 = 1.0 # less than pi
8731 x2 = 4.0 # greater than pi
8732 c = 0.75
8733 p = stats.wrapcauchy.cdf([x1, x2], c)
8734 cr = (1 + c)/(1 - c)
8735 assert_allclose(p[0], np.arctan(cr*np.tan(x1/2))/np.pi)
8736 assert_allclose(p[1], 1 - np.arctan(cr*np.tan(np.pi - x2/2))/np.pi)
8737
8738
8739def test_rvs_no_size_error():
8740 # _rvs methods must have parameter `size`; see gh-11394
8741 class rvs_no_size_gen(stats.rv_continuous):
8742 def _rvs(self):
8743 return 1
8744
8745 rvs_no_size = rvs_no_size_gen(name='rvs_no_size')
8746
8747 with assert_raises(TypeError, match=r"_rvs\‍(\‍) got (an|\d) unexpected"):
8748 rvs_no_size.rvs()
8749
8750
8751@pytest.mark.parametrize('distname, args', invdistdiscrete + invdistcont)
8752def test_support_gh13294_regression(distname, args):
8753 if distname in skip_test_support_gh13294_regression:
8754 pytest.skip(f"skipping test for the support method for "
8755 f"distribution {distname}.")
8756 dist = getattr(stats, distname)
8757 # test support method with invalid arguents
8758 if isinstance(dist, stats.rv_continuous):
8759 # test with valid scale
8760 if len(args) != 0:
8761 a0, b0 = dist.support(*args)
8762 assert_equal(a0, np.nan)
8763 assert_equal(b0, np.nan)
8764 # test with invalid scale
8765 # For some distributions, that take no parameters,
8766 # the case of only invalid scale occurs and hence,
8767 # it is implicitly tested in this test case.
8768 loc1, scale1 = 0, -1
8769 a1, b1 = dist.support(*args, loc1, scale1)
8770 assert_equal(a1, np.nan)
8771 assert_equal(b1, np.nan)
8772 else:
8773 a, b = dist.support(*args)
8774 assert_equal(a, np.nan)
8775 assert_equal(b, np.nan)
8776
8777
8778def test_support_broadcasting_gh13294_regression():
8779 a0, b0 = stats.norm.support([0, 0, 0, 1], [1, 1, 1, -1])
8780 ex_a0 = np.array([-np.inf, -np.inf, -np.inf, np.nan])
8781 ex_b0 = np.array([np.inf, np.inf, np.inf, np.nan])
8782 assert_equal(a0, ex_a0)
8783 assert_equal(b0, ex_b0)
8784 assert a0.shape == ex_a0.shape
8785 assert b0.shape == ex_b0.shape
8786
8787 a1, b1 = stats.norm.support([], [])
8788 ex_a1, ex_b1 = np.array([]), np.array([])
8789 assert_equal(a1, ex_a1)
8790 assert_equal(b1, ex_b1)
8791 assert a1.shape == ex_a1.shape
8792 assert b1.shape == ex_b1.shape
8793
8794 a2, b2 = stats.norm.support([0, 0, 0, 1], [-1])
8795 ex_a2 = np.array(4*[np.nan])
8796 ex_b2 = np.array(4*[np.nan])
8797 assert_equal(a2, ex_a2)
8798 assert_equal(b2, ex_b2)
8799 assert a2.shape == ex_a2.shape
8800 assert b2.shape == ex_b2.shape
8801
8802
8803def test_stats_broadcasting_gh14953_regression():
8804 # test case in gh14953
8805 loc = [0., 0.]
8806 scale = [[1.], [2.], [3.]]
8807 assert_equal(stats.norm.var(loc, scale), [[1., 1.], [4., 4.], [9., 9.]])
8808 # test some edge cases
8809 loc = np.empty((0, ))
8810 scale = np.empty((1, 0))
8811 assert stats.norm.var(loc, scale).shape == (1, 0)
8812
8813
8814# Check a few values of the cosine distribution's cdf, sf, ppf and
8815# isf methods. Expected values were computed with mpmath.
8816
8817@pytest.mark.parametrize('x, expected',
8818 [(-3.14159, 4.956444476505336e-19),
8819 (3.14, 0.9999999998928399)])
8820def test_cosine_cdf_sf(x, expected):
8821 assert_allclose(stats.cosine.cdf(x), expected)
8822 assert_allclose(stats.cosine.sf(-x), expected)
8823
8824
8825@pytest.mark.parametrize('p, expected',
8826 [(1e-6, -3.1080612413765905),
8827 (1e-17, -3.141585429601399),
8828 (0.975, 2.1447547020964923)])
8829def test_cosine_ppf_isf(p, expected):
8830 assert_allclose(stats.cosine.ppf(p), expected)
8831 assert_allclose(stats.cosine.isf(p), -expected)
8832
8833
8834def test_cosine_logpdf_endpoints():
8835 logp = stats.cosine.logpdf([-np.pi, np.pi])
8836 # reference value calculated using mpmath assuming `np.cos(-1)` is four
8837 # floating point numbers too high. See gh-18382.
8838 assert_array_less(logp, -37.18838327496655)
8839
8840
8841def test_distr_params_lists():
8842 # distribution objects are extra distributions added in
8843 # test_discrete_basic. All other distributions are strings (names)
8844 # and so we only choose those to compare whether both lists match.
8845 discrete_distnames = {name for name, _ in distdiscrete
8846 if isinstance(name, str)}
8847 invdiscrete_distnames = {name for name, _ in invdistdiscrete}
8848 assert discrete_distnames == invdiscrete_distnames
8849
8850 cont_distnames = {name for name, _ in distcont}
8851 invcont_distnames = {name for name, _ in invdistcont}
8852 assert cont_distnames == invcont_distnames
8853
8854
8855def test_moment_order_4():
8856 # gh-13655 reported that if a distribution has a `_stats` method that
8857 # accepts the `moments` parameter, then if the distribution's `moment`
8858 # method is called with `order=4`, the faster/more accurate`_stats` gets
8859 # called, but the results aren't used, and the generic `_munp` method is
8860 # called to calculate the moment anyway. This tests that the issue has
8861 # been fixed.
8862 # stats.skewnorm._stats accepts the `moments` keyword
8863 stats.skewnorm._stats(a=0, moments='k') # no failure = has `moments`
8864 # When `moment` is called, `_stats` is used, so the moment is very accurate
8865 # (exactly equal to Pearson's kurtosis of the normal distribution, 3)
8866 assert stats.skewnorm.moment(order=4, a=0) == 3.0
8867 # At the time of gh-13655, skewnorm._munp() used the generic method
8868 # to compute its result, which was inefficient and not very accurate.
8869 # At that time, the following assertion would fail. skewnorm._munp()
8870 # has since been made more accurate and efficient, so now this test
8871 # is expected to pass.
8872 assert stats.skewnorm._munp(4, 0) == 3.0
8873
8874
8875class TestRelativisticBW:
8876 @pytest.fixture
8877 def ROOT_pdf_sample_data(self):
8878 """Sample data points for pdf computed with CERN's ROOT
8879
8880 See - https://root.cern/
8881
8882 Uses ROOT.TMath.BreitWignerRelativistic, available in ROOT
8883 versions 6.27+
8884
8885 pdf calculated for Z0 Boson, W Boson, and Higgs Boson for
8886 x in `np.linspace(0, 200, 401)`.
8887 """
8888 data = np.load(
8889 Path(__file__).parent /
8890 'data/rel_breitwigner_pdf_sample_data_ROOT.npy'
8891 )
8892 data = np.core.records.fromarrays(data.T, names='x,pdf,rho,gamma')
8893 return data
8894
8895 @pytest.mark.parametrize(
8896 "rho,gamma,rtol", [
8897 (36.545206797050334, 2.4952, 5e-14), # Z0 Boson
8898 (38.55107913669065, 2.085, 1e-14), # W Boson
8899 (96292.3076923077, 0.0013, 5e-13), # Higgs Boson
8900 ]
8901 )
8902 def test_pdf_against_ROOT(self, ROOT_pdf_sample_data, rho, gamma, rtol):
8903 data = ROOT_pdf_sample_data[
8904 (ROOT_pdf_sample_data['rho'] == rho)
8905 & (ROOT_pdf_sample_data['gamma'] == gamma)
8906 ]
8907 x, pdf = data['x'], data['pdf']
8908 assert_allclose(
8909 pdf, stats.rel_breitwigner.pdf(x, rho, scale=gamma), rtol=rtol
8910 )
8911
8912 @pytest.mark.parametrize("rho, Gamma, rtol", [
8913 (36.545206797050334, 2.4952, 5e-13), # Z0 Boson
8914 (38.55107913669065, 2.085, 5e-13), # W Boson
8915 (96292.3076923077, 0.0013, 5e-10), # Higgs Boson
8916 ]
8917 )
8918 def test_pdf_against_simple_implementation(self, rho, Gamma, rtol):
8919 # reference implementation straight from formulas on Wikipedia [1]
8920 def pdf(E, M, Gamma):
8921 gamma = np.sqrt(M**2 * (M**2 + Gamma**2))
8922 k = (2 * np.sqrt(2) * M * Gamma * gamma
8923 / (np.pi * np.sqrt(M**2 + gamma)))
8924 return k / ((E**2 - M**2)**2 + M**2*Gamma**2)
8925 # get reasonable values at which to evaluate the CDF
8926 p = np.linspace(0.05, 0.95, 10)
8927 x = stats.rel_breitwigner.ppf(p, rho, scale=Gamma)
8928 res = stats.rel_breitwigner.pdf(x, rho, scale=Gamma)
8929 ref = pdf(x, rho*Gamma, Gamma)
8930 assert_allclose(res, ref, rtol=rtol)
8931
8932 @pytest.mark.parametrize(
8933 "rho,gamma", [
8934 pytest.param(
8935 36.545206797050334, 2.4952, marks=pytest.mark.slow
8936 ), # Z0 Boson
8937 pytest.param(
8938 38.55107913669065, 2.085, marks=pytest.mark.xslow
8939 ), # W Boson
8940 pytest.param(
8941 96292.3076923077, 0.0013, marks=pytest.mark.xslow
8942 ), # Higgs Boson
8943 ]
8944 )
8945 def test_fit_floc(self, rho, gamma):
8946 """Tests fit for cases where floc is set.
8947
8948 `rel_breitwigner` has special handling for these cases.
8949 """
8950 seed = 6936804688480013683
8951 rng = np.random.default_rng(seed)
8952 data = stats.rel_breitwigner.rvs(
8953 rho, scale=gamma, size=1000, random_state=rng
8954 )
8955 fit = stats.rel_breitwigner.fit(data, floc=0)
8956 assert_allclose((fit[0], fit[2]), (rho, gamma), rtol=2e-1)
8957 assert fit[1] == 0
8958 # Check again with fscale set.
8959 fit = stats.rel_breitwigner.fit(data, floc=0, fscale=gamma)
8960 assert_allclose(fit[0], rho, rtol=1e-2)
8961 assert (fit[1], fit[2]) == (0, gamma)
8962
8963
8964class TestJohnsonSU:
8965 @pytest.mark.parametrize("case", [ # a, b, loc, scale, m1, m2, g1, g2
8966 (-0.01, 1.1, 0.02, 0.0001, 0.02000137427557091,
8967 2.1112742956578063e-08, 0.05989781342460999, 20.36324408592951-3),
8968 (2.554395574161155, 2.2482281679651965, 0, 1, -1.54215386737391,
8969 0.7629882028469993, -1.256656139406788, 6.303058419339775-3)])
8970 def test_moment_gh18071(self, case):
8971 # gh-18071 reported an IntegrationWarning emitted by johnsonsu.stats
8972 # Check that the warning is no longer emitted and that the values
8973 # are accurate compared against results from Mathematica.
8974 # Reference values from Mathematica, e.g.
8975 # Mean[JohnsonDistribution["SU",-0.01, 1.1, 0.02, 0.0001]]
8976 res = stats.johnsonsu.stats(*case[:4], moments='mvsk')
8977 assert_allclose(res, case[4:], rtol=1e-14)
8978
8979
8980class TestTruncPareto:
8981 def test_pdf(self):
8982 # PDF is that of the truncated pareto distribution
8983 b, c = 1.8, 5.3
8984 x = np.linspace(1.8, 5.3)
8985 res = stats.truncpareto(b, c).pdf(x)
8986 ref = stats.pareto(b).pdf(x) / stats.pareto(b).cdf(c)
8987 assert_allclose(res, ref)
8988
8989 @pytest.mark.parametrize('fix_loc', [True, False])
8990 @pytest.mark.parametrize('fix_scale', [True, False])
8991 @pytest.mark.parametrize('fix_b', [True, False])
8992 @pytest.mark.parametrize('fix_c', [True, False])
8993 def test_fit(self, fix_loc, fix_scale, fix_b, fix_c):
8994
8995 rng = np.random.default_rng(6747363148258237171)
8996 b, c, loc, scale = 1.8, 5.3, 1, 2.5
8997 dist = stats.truncpareto(b, c, loc=loc, scale=scale)
8998 data = dist.rvs(size=500, random_state=rng)
8999
9000 kwds = {}
9001 if fix_loc:
9002 kwds['floc'] = loc
9003 if fix_scale:
9004 kwds['fscale'] = scale
9005 if fix_b:
9006 kwds['f0'] = b
9007 if fix_c:
9008 kwds['f1'] = c
9009
9010 if fix_loc and fix_scale and fix_b and fix_c:
9011 message = "All parameters fixed. There is nothing to optimize."
9012 with pytest.raises(RuntimeError, match=message):
9013 stats.truncpareto.fit(data, **kwds)
9014 else:
9015 _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.truncpareto, data, **kwds)
function
